div.head:
4225. Robert Southey to Peter Elmsley, 5 August 1824 MS: Westminster School. ALS; 4p.
Previously published: Nicholas Horsfall, ‘Four Unpublished Letters of Robert Southey’, Notes and Queries, 22.9 (September 1975), 403–405.
div.p: Among all the persons who have rejoiced in your recovery, there is probably no one who has felt the kind of pleasure which has fallen to my lot. I received a letter from Mrs Hughes telling me you were dead. I thought of you & dreamt of you as of the dead, – & continued in that belief till there came news from Bedford that thxx xxxxx he was going to visit you, & witness the progress of your amendment. Never before did any letter give me so much delight, – & most likely xx unlikely it is that any one ever will hereafter.

A severe illness is middle life sometimes leaves the constitution in a better state than it found it. The vis medicatrixA contraction of ‘vis medicatrix naturae’: literally ‘the healing power of nature’. This is the Latin version of a phrase attributed to Hippocrates (c. 460–c. 370 BC), Greek physician. in such cases goes to work like a landlord, who having neglected his house till it threatens to fall down, sets about a thorough repair.

On Thursd the 12th of this month I shall compleat the fiftieth year of my age. My tenement has some ugly flaws in it, tho it has stood pretty well, all circumstances considered. For more than twenty years I have been subject to a severe & obstinate catarrh, beginning with the summer, & lasting ten or twelve weeks: nor have I ever escaped it except the year when I went into Switzerland at the time of its usual visitation.Southey’s visit to the Continent in May–August 1817. Latterly it has always ended in a cough, & this year that cough has for the first time given me a hint of its hereditary right to fix upon me. – I am getting rid of it for the present, & have nearly recovered the strength which I had lost. But so surely as the seasons come round, so surely will the affection return, unless I can arm the system against it by a course of exercise & constant change of air at that time. If therefore it be possible, I will pass the months latter end of May, & the six following weeks next year in travelling Holland & the North of Germany.Southey did indeed make this journey in 1825 and 1826.

I am printing the second vol. of the Peninsular War,Southey’s History of the Peninsular War (1823–1832). & more meo‘as is my custom’. writing it <one chapter> while the press is going on with another. Tho this may not be a good method, there are some good reasons for it, – the best being that it enables me to use <employ> the latest materials which fall in my way, more advantageously than xx <if> they came only in time to be used for correcting a narrative drawn from documents less satisfactory documents. This is a very sufficient reason. My materials are as authentic as I could desire, & as ample as would be desired by any person except myself. The D. of Wellington would not supply me with any papers, for a reason which Wynn has probably told you,Southey believed that Wellington was reserving his help for Sir William Napier (1785–1860; DNB), History of the War in the Peninsula and the South of France from the Year 1807 to 1814 (1828–1840). Napier did indeed receive much assistance from Wellington, but was not given use of his papers. but thro Wynn he will give me any information I may have occasion to ask that can be communicated in x viva voce.‘by word of mouth’. He would have done better in committing his papers to my hands, than in reserving them for a mere military history, – to which purpose they would have been equally applicable afterwards. But I have from others had so much both of his official & confidential correspondence during those years while he hxx was fighting up hill, – that perhaps he would be very much surprized to know how well I am acquainted with his views, feelings & opinions. So well indeed am I provided with documents, & with that previous knowledge which is necessary for turning them to account, that I proceed with full confidence & a firm step every where, – except upon a field of battle: – there indeed I am as sensible as I ought to be of my own ignorance; & when I have done my best to understand what to my non-military & non-mathematical head xx xxxx <is> unintelligible. I stick to the letter of my authorities & make the reader as wise as myself. When I come to these parts of the story, xx my own situation puts me in mind of a Cat upon a tea table, – if you ever saw one picking her way among the cups & saucers.

Should it please Gods, Men & Booksellers I am thinking of a Book of the StateSouthey did not write ‘The Book of the State’ as a companion to The Book of the Church (1824). – to be brought down to the death of Q Anne,Anne (1665–1714; Queen of Great Britain 1701–1714; DNB). – & connected by an introductory view of the reigns of George 1 & 2, with a xxx the Age of George 3,George I (1660–1727; King of Great Britain 1701–1727; DNB); George II (1683–1760; King of Great Britain 1727–1760; DNB); and George III (1738–1820; King of Great Britain 1760–1820; DNB). – making thus a summary of our English history upon a scale & in a form likely to be read & remembered. Want of books is the chief obstacle, & there need be no greater. I have lately read three works which would have made one part of my Eccl. SketchSouthey’s The Book of the Church (1824). much less imperfect than it is, if I had perused them in time. Cardinal D’Ossat’s Letters,Arnaud D’Ossat (1537–1604), Lettres du Cardinal d’Ossat, avec des Notes Historiques et Politiques de M. Amelot De La Houssaie (1708), no. 851 in the sale catalogue of Southey’s library. Isaac Casaubons Epistles,Isaac Casaubon (1559–1614), Epistolae (1656), no. 453 in the sale catalogue of Southey’s library. & Peter Heylyns View of Guernsey & Jersey.Peter Heylyn (1600–1662; DNB), A Survey of the Estate of France and Some of the Adjoyning Ilands (1656), no. 1187 in the sale catalogue of Southey’s library. One motive with me for undertaking a sketch of our Civil History would be for the opportunity it would afford of introducing there whatever of importance had been omitted in the former work.

These are speculations, which with many others of a wider scope & perhaps a worthier purpose, – time & chance may easily frustrate. Meantime – sufficient for the day is the occupation thereof. How glad should I be to talk with you over the past – the present – & the future, – here at leisure & at rest! – & I hope this will Whatever enjoyment there may be in meeting in London society (& I am far from undervaluing it,) there is nothing of this kind to be had in crowds. One day I hope to have you again under this roof.Elmsley had visited Southey at Keswick in September 1805. Pleasure & profit are not always united, but in that case I should find them so; – for mine is a mind upon which good seed is not wasted – tho it is sometimes long in springing up & bringing forth fruit.
